data:
{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3624939,"name":"Ethan Grieshop","username":"CakeDeer6","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/cakedeer6/{size}/264680_2.png","created_at":"2025-05-15T03:32:25.847Z","cooked":"

If a team could hypothetically switch gear ratios while accelerating, they could get both low end torque and a high top speed, which would’ve been overpowered for games like Crescendo, where you have long open-field cycles but could also face defense, where you need the extra force. Obviously, this would come with drawbacks such as weight, complexity, and robustness, but could there be a world where this is a viable strategy for a top team?

","post_number":1,"post_type":1,"posts_count":12,"updated_at":"2025-05-15T03:32:25.847Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":26,"reads":600,"readers_count":599,"score":280.0,"yours":false,"topic_id":501778,"topic_slug":"could-a-swerve-drive-with-a-gear-shift-outperform","display_username":"Ethan Grieshop","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":2}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":62698,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"4611 Programmer + Driver"},"post_url":"/t/could-a-swerve-drive-with-a-gear-shift-outperform/501778/1","custom_user_title":"4611 Programmer + Driver","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":2},{"id":"thinking","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":3,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null,"can_vote":false},{"id":3624951,"name":"Billfred Leverette (he/him/not Bill)","username":"Billfred","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/billfred/{size}/225278_2.png","created_at":"2025-05-15T03:48:53.802Z","cooked":"

I know a couple teams have experimented with it; I forget who was showing that off in their pit at Championship 2022. If there was that much of an edge, I feel like someone would’ve mopped the floor with the rest of us by now.

2557 did so in 2023, moved to COTS swerve in 2024.

1640 has done custom shifting and CVT swerve modules quite a few times.

1640 Sab-BOT-age 2020 CVT Swerve Module Reveal Robot Showcase
1640, Sab-BOT-age, is proud to present our 2020 CVT Swerve Module. [render1] Our 2017-2019 CVT swerve was designed to add CVT functionality on top of our standard swerve module, which has only seen iterative changes since its inception in 2010. While this provided us a lot of success and the base swerve module was robust, proven, and reliable, it provided for a suboptimal implementation of CVT. Over the last 2 years, we have spent countless hours redesigning our swerve module from the ground …

Their swerve wiki, for reference:
https://team1640.com/wiki/index.php/Swerve_Central

","post_number":4,"post_type":1,"posts_count":12,"updated_at":"2025-05-15T06:12:40.726Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":7,"reads":540,"readers_count":539,"score":293.0,"yours":false,"topic_id":501778,"topic_slug":"could-a-swerve-drive-with-a-gear-shift-outperform","display_username":"Brandon King","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"link_counts":[{"url":"https://team1640.com/wiki/index.php/Swerve_Central","internal":false,"reflection":false,"title":"Swerve Central - DEW Robotics","clicks":38},{"url":"https://www.chiefdelphi.com/t/1640-sab-bot-age-2020-cvt-swerve-module-reveal/368492","internal":true,"reflection":false,"title":"1640 Sab-BOT-age 2020 CVT Swerve Module Reveal","clicks":0}],"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":10}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":19708,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"2910 Mentor"},"post_url":"/t/could-a-swerve-drive-with-a-gear-shift-outperform/501778/4","custom_user_title":"2910 Mentor","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":10}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":10,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3625076,"name":"Skye Leake","username":"Skyehawk","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/skyehawk/{size}/179363_2.png","created_at":"2025-05-15T10:58:34.469Z","cooked":"

From a swerve history standpoint this thread has some of the attempts and discussions of the (dis) advantages through the years.

Shifting swerve Manufacturing
Curious if anyone has a working concept for a shifting swerve drive they’d be willing to share. We really utilized shifting gearboxes on our differential chassis. A fellow mentor brought it up to me at the Idaho Regional.

My personal opinion: in the age of brushless, shifting gearboxes are somewhat defeated. Furthermore, with swerve “slow is smooth, smooth is fast”, in other words—for most games it isn’t a pure power question, rather one of precision.

","post_number":5,"post_type":1,"posts_count":12,"updated_at":"2025-05-15T11:02:19.562Z","reply_count":3,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":1,"reads":459,"readers_count":458,"score":291.8,"yours":false,"topic_id":501778,"topic_slug":"could-a-swerve-drive-with-a-gear-shift-outperform","display_username":"Skye Leake","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"link_counts":[{"url":"https://www.chiefdelphi.com/t/shifting-swerve/460151","internal":true,"reflection":false,"title":"Shifting swerve","clicks":0}],"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":12}],"moderator":true,"admin":false,"staff":true,"user_id":19235,"hidden":false,"trust_level":4,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"Pretengineer"},"post_url":"/t/could-a-swerve-drive-with-a-gear-shift-outperform/501778/5","custom_user_title":"Pretengineer","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":12}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":12,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3625096,"name":"Richard Wallace","username":"Richard_Wallace","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/richard_wallace/{size}/110760_2.png","created_at":"2025-05-15T11:51:16.538Z","cooked":"
Skyehawk:

“slow is smooth, smooth is fast”

Mark says that frequently, and do several others in the 2767 cluster.

In the factory we value the people who get a job done in minimum time; we actively discourage running up and down the aisles.

","post_number":6,"post_type":1,"posts_count":12,"updated_at":"2025-05-15T11:51:16.538Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":5,"quote_count":1,"incoming_link_count":7,"reads":420,"readers_count":419,"score":184.0,"yours":false,"topic_id":501778,"topic_slug":"could-a-swerve-drive-with-a-gear-shift-outperform","display_username":"Richard Wallace","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":4}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":1549,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"I live for the details."},"post_url":"/t/could-a-swerve-drive-with-a-gear-shift-outperform/501778/6","custom_user_title":"I live for the details.","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":4}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":4,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3625121,"name":"Max Morehead","username":"Max_Morehead","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/max_morehead/{size}/231937_2.png","created_at":"2025-05-15T12:57:23.710Z","cooked":"

In theory, there is some small advantage in games with full field sprints, since with optimally fast gearings you are limited by motor torque rather than wheel traction at low speeds. I would guess the theoretical advantage in sprint times would be something in the 10-20% range. It would also save some battery energy over fast fixed gearing. It certainly seems better for performance to me than the 8 drive motor swerves we saw in 2023, and some of the teams that did that liked it.

As with anything in FRC, opportunity cost is everything. Only the very best teams lose matches because their drivetrain isn’t fast enough. Most teams lose matches because their mechanism are not reliable enough. Focus your effort where it’s most going to help your performance.

Also, there’s a practical consideration that limits a variable speed drivetrain. Compared to a fixed speed drivetrain with the same max speed, the variable speed drivetrain accelerates faster. But for every FRC robot I’ve helped with, we’ve had to limit the acceleration so the robot was less jerky, easier to drive, and to prevent tipping in 2023. So if you do that, you are completely nullifying the advantage.

","post_number":7,"post_type":1,"posts_count":12,"updated_at":"2025-05-15T13:52:46.875Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":2,"reads":352,"readers_count":351,"score":115.4,"yours":false,"topic_id":501778,"topic_slug":"could-a-swerve-drive-with-a-gear-shift-outperform","display_username":"Max Morehead","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":3,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":2}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":53784,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"Mentor"},"post_url":"/t/could-a-swerve-drive-with-a-gear-shift-outperform/501778/7","custom_user_title":"Mentor","reactions":[{"id":"point_up","type":"emoji","count":2}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":2,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3625139,"name":"Mike","username":"Mike_FRC_56","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/mike_frc_56/{size}/178961_2.png","created_at":"2025-05-15T13:14:08.798Z","cooked":"

You also need to consider the coefficient of friction between the wheels and the carpet.

Under high-torque conditions (like trying to push another robot out of the way) you will reach a limit where additional torque at the wheels doesn’t make you move the robot but instead causes the wheels to spin in place. Once that happens, more torque just makes you burn holes in the carpet more effectively.

","post_number":8,"post_type":1,"posts_count":12,"updated_at":"2025-05-15T13:14:08.798Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":293,"readers_count":292,"score":73.6,"yours":false,"topic_id":501778,"topic_slug":"could-a-swerve-drive-with-a-gear-shift-outperform","display_username":"Mike","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":1}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":50093,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"post_url":"/t/could-a-swerve-drive-with-a-gear-shift-outperform/501778/8","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":1,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3625170,"name":"Kooper","username":"Kquig","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/kquig/{size}/268644_2.png","created_at":"2025-05-15T13:47:17.246Z","cooked":"

“slow is smooth, smooth is fast”,

this is basically our lead mentor’s motto for everything robotics

Team 5687 implemented this in 2024. They were super good at getting around defense with it.

5687, The Outliers, CAD release and our 2024 robot Barry Robot Showcase
The Outliers are proud to present their 2024 robot Barry. Please note that several changes were made late in the season that were not fully updated in the CAD model. If you have any questions, don’t hesitate to ask! Additionally, to keep the model lighter, we omitted some symmetric components. [image] Barry’s design was build around our shifting swerves, which utilized a ball shifter actuated by a pneumatic cylinder. The gear ratios were set at 6.86:1 for low gear and 4.51:1 for high gear, pr…
